CONJUGATES: demerits (n. pl.) | demerits (v. 3rd p. sg. pres.) | demerited (v. past t./p.p.) | demeriting (v. pres. p.)
ETYMOLOGY: From Old French demerite (fault, blame), from Latin demeritum (a fault, bad service), from demereri (to deserve ill, incur a penalty), from de- (down, away) + mereri (to deserve).
SINCE: Late 15th century (as noun), mid-17th century (as verb)

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word that functions as the name of a specific object or set of objects, such as a person, place, thing, quality, or idea.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A fault or disadvantage; a mark recorded against a person for misconduct or failure, especially in a school or military setting.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 缺点；过失；过错记号（尤指学校或军队中对学生的惩罚记录）
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He received a demerit for being late to class for the third time this week.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他因本周第三次上课迟到而得到一个过失记号。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word that describes an action, state, or occurrence.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To record a demerit against someone; to incur a demerit; to reduce the merit of.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 记录过失；扣分；减损…的优点
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The school regulations allow teachers to demerit students for severe infractions.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 学校规章允许老师因严重违规而给学生记录过失。

REGISTER: Formal and often administrative or institutional, particularly common in educational or military contexts.
